journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment

title-group.article-title: Hydrodynamic behaviours of elastic net sheets in waves

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Takeshi Kinoshita, Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, 4-6-1 Komaba, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 153-8505, Japan. Email: kinoshit@iis.u-tokyo.ac.jp

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Hydroelasticity Theories and Applications

abstract.p: From previous experimental investigations on a heaving sea cage, it has been observed that the hydrodynamic forces and motions of the sea cage are strongly affected by the deformation of the cage net. As a fundamental study, the hydrodynamic behaviours of elastic net sheets with a circular or a square shape are studied in the present work. The net sheet is regarded as a piece of elastic porous membrane. The deformation of the net sheet is expanded into a series of natural modes deduced from the free vibration of the membrane (dry mode). The boundary value problem of fluid motion is formulated on the basis of the linear wave theory. A Darcy-type law is applied to the porous boundary. The problem is solved either by the eigenfunction expansion (for the circular shape only) or by the hybrid method with the Rankine source as the Green’s function. To validate the theoretical work and the numerical calculation, experiments are carried out in a wave basin. The models used in the tests are square shaped with a metal frame. The net part of the models is made of elastic cords with pre-tension. Both diffraction tests and forced heaving tests are performed. In addition to the vertical force, the deformation of the net surface is recorded by video cameras and analysed with a video image analysis system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, with decreasing ocean resources and expanding needs on seafood, the production from only marine fishery can hardly meet the demand from the fish market. Increasingly, attention has been focused on the aquaculture industry. Traditional aquaculture farms are generally located in sheltered inshore areas. The expansion of the cultured production is limited owing to the environmental problems and lack of available bay areas. Therefore, offshore aquaculture, which has various advantages, has been considered by investors. Offshore aquaculture is a promising system for providing cultured fish with a high productivity and a high quality. As the sea cages are moved to a deeper and open sea area, water exchange becomes easier. It brings clean sea water that is rich in oxygen into the sea cages. There is less influence on the environment since the settlement of sea lice and fouling organisms is reduced.1 In addition, large-scale aquaculture is more cost effective.2 Meanwhile, a new challenge is also confronted. It is an important issue to protect offshore farms from a severe sea state caused by bad weather such as typhoons and hurricanes. In order to reduce the environmental loads from waves, most sea cages are submerged in an offshore area. During the past decade, various types of sea cage installed at exposed sea sites have been developed in the world. The behaviour of sea cages in waves has been investigated. For example, large submergible cages, named Sea Station, have been developed by Ocean Spar to avoid the damage caused by a harsh environment. The University of New Hampshire has been involved in a project on open ocean aquaculture.3 Fredriksson and his research group4 have studied the heave response of a central spar sea cage (Sea Station). Later, Fredriksson et al. investigated the mooring forces of a single sea cage5 as well as an array of sea cages.6,7 An experimental investigation of the wave forces on net structures has been made by Lader et al.8,9

In many cases, sea cages are usually made of net materials. An interesting problem is raised, i.e. how to evaluate the deformation of the net and its effect on the hydrodynamic loads in an efficient way. One of the possible approaches is to regard the net as a piece of elastic porous membrane. Some researchers, who are interested in the breakwater effect of a submerged elastic or rigid porous plate have investigated this subject. To give some examples, the downstream waves of a submerged rigid porous plate have been investigated by Yu and Chwang.10 A submerged porous flexible membrane has been studied by Cho and Kim.11,12 Comparison has also been made between calculation and measurement in their work. The above-mentioned investigations are all involved with two-dimensional problems.

In the present work, the hydrodynamic behaviour of a porous net sheet is investigated by means of linear hydroelastic theory and experimental tests. The shape of the net sheet is either a circle or a rectangle. The net sheet is regarded as a porous membrane. The deformation of the net is expressed by an expansion of the natural modes, the modal functions of which are deduced from the free vibration of a circular or rectangular membrane. The net sheet is horizontally fixed in a train of incoming waves or forced to make a heaving oscillation in still water. The formulated diffraction and radiation problems are solved by means of the eigenfunction expansion for the circular sheet. To solve the boundary value problem for an arbitrarily shaped net sheet, a hybrid method is adopted in the present work. The modal amplitudes of deformation are solved from the motion equation and their effects on the hydrodynamic forces are examined. To validate the theoretical work and numerical calculation, a series of experimental tests is carried out in a wave basin. The calculated hydrodynamic forces and net deformation are compared with the measured data.

The boundary value problem is formulated in the next section. The modal functions to express the net deformation are deduced in the third section, and the approaches to solve the boundary value problem are discussed in the fourth section. This is followed by a section on the motion equation and hydrodynamic forces. The experimental arrangement is presented in the sixth section. The calculated and measured results are compared in the seventh section. The paper ends with a brief conclusion.

sec.title: Formulation of the problem
sec.p: In a water of constant depth h, a net sheet is horizontally installed at a distance d beneath the water surface. The shape of the sheet is either circular or rectangular. The radius of the circle is denoted as a while the lengths of the rectangular sides are taken as 2a and 2b respectively. In addition to a Cartesian frame (x, y, z), a polar coordinate system (r, θ, z) is adopted to describe the problem in the case of a circular net with the transform relations x = r cosθ and y = r sinθ. The x–y plane, or equivalently the r–θ plane, coincides with the still water surface while the z axis goes through the centre of the net and points upwards (Figure 1).

caption.p: Definition of the coordinate system and the division of the fluid domain: (a) circular net; (b) rectangular net.

sec.p: The net sheet, tightened with a uniform tension T, is fixed in a train of regular incident waves or forced to make a heaving oscillation about its average position z = –d. The frequency of the incident waves or the forced heaving oscillation is denoted as ω. The interaction of the net sheet with the ambient wave field is considered within the scope of the linear hydroelastic theory. This means that the net sheet is treated as an elastic porous membrane, the deformation of which is represented by a set of the natural modes given by

where ζmn represents the unknown complex modal amplitude corresponding to the mnth mode. The deformation is assumed to be small so that the displacement can be considered in the z direction. The definition of the modal function Wmn(x), together with the range of the indices m and n, will be given in the next section.
As the fluid motion is considered, under the assumption that the fluid is inviscid and the flow is irrotational, there exists a velocity potential Φ(x, t), which may be decomposed into the form

In equation (2), the amplitude of the incident wave is denoted by A while the heaving amplitude is represented by ηH. g is the acceleration due to gravity. The diffraction potential φD consists of the incident wave potential φI and the scattering potential φS, i.e. φD = φI+φS. The incident wave potential φI is well known. For convenience in later use, its expression and the Fourier–Bessel expansion are recorded here as
where β is the incident wave angle.

The radiation potential φH is caused by the forced heaving oscillation when the net sheet is regarded as a rigid body. The generalized radiation potential ϕmn is the fluid motion due to the deformation of the net sheet corresponding to the mnth natural mode.
All the potentials are governed by the Laplace equation with a linearized free-surface condition and an impermeable sea bottom condition as shown below

In equations (4) to (6), the subscript j corresponds to the letter S or H or runs over all the possible combination of the indices m and n, to indicate the diffraction or the radiation potentials (including the generalized values) respectively.

On the body surface, i.e. the net sheet, it is treated as a porous membrane. According to the fine-pore assumption used in many previous studies, a Darcy-type law is applied to this part of the boundary. It is stated as the fact that the normal velocity is continuous through the porous boundary and is proportional to the pressure difference between the two sides of the boundary. Hence, the boundary condition at the net sheet may be written as

where the porous-effect parameter is represented by σ, which is a real number in the present work. Its value varies from 0 to ∞. When σ = 0, the surface is impermeable. Contrarily, when σ = ∞, it becomes completely permeable, i.e. the net does not exist. The variable nj denotes the normal velocity of the body, which is defined as
To ensure the unique existence of the solution, the scattering and radiation potentials should satisfy the so-called Sommerfeld condition at far field, which is given by
where k0 is the wave number. It is related to the wave frequency ω by the dispersion relation ν = ω2/g = k0 tanh(k0h).

sec.title: Natural modes of deformation
sec.p: As mentioned in the previous section, the net sheet is regarded as a membrane and its deformation is expanded into a series of the natural modes (see equation (1)). The modal function Wmn(x) is the solution of the free vibration equation for a pre-tensioned membrane, which is given in many textbooks (see, for example, the book by Meirovitch13) and can be expressed as
where ∇22 is the two-dimensional Laplace operator given by
The parameter β¯ is defined as β¯2=ρ¯ϖ2/T, where ρ¯ is the density of the membrane per unit area while ϖ is the natural frequency of the oscillation.
In addition, the membrane is fixed at its brim. Hence, the modal function satisfies a boundary condition such as
for a circularly shaped membrane and
in the case of a rectangular shape.
The Helmholtz equation (10) can be solved analytically in special cases such as a circle or a rectangle.
In the case of a circular membrane, the solution is the product of the first-kind Bessel functions and trigonometric functions, namely

In equation (14) the eigenvalue β¯mn is determined by substituting the solution into the boundary condition (12). It leads to a value β¯mn=xmn/a with xmn as the mth zero of the Bessel function Jn(x). To make it single valued, the index n must be an integer (i.e. n = 0, 1, 2, …) while the index m (m = 1, 2, …) counts the zeros of the Bessel functions.
In the case of a rectangular membrane, the modal function is the product of two trigonometric functions, i.e.
Here, the eigenvalue
To ensure that the boundary conditions (equation (13)) are satisfied, the indices m and n must be integers, i.e. m, n = 1, 2, ….

These modal functions are normal to each other. This means that the integration of the product of two modal functions over the whole membrane area vanishes unless the two functions are the same, as given by

where δij is the Kronecker delta function, which equals 1 if i = j and equals 0 if i≠j. S denotes the total area of the membrane, which equals a2 for a circle and equals 4ab for a rectangle. The coefficient of the modal function, i.e. Cmn in equation (14) or 2 in equation (15), is so chosen to ensure the above integral is equal to the area S of the membrane for the same two modal functions.

sec.title: Solution of the velocity potentials
sec.p: In this section, the boundary value problem formulated in the second section is going to be solved. Different approaches are used for circular net sheets and rectangular net sheets and are discussed in the following sections respectively.

sec.title: Method of eigenfunction expansion
sec.p: In the case of a circular net sheet, the boundary value problem is solved by means of the eigenfunction expansion. The fluid domain is divided into two regions. Region I is the exterior part defined by r > a, while the interior part, i.e. r < a, is named region II (see Figure 1(a)). Different eigenfunctions are used in these two regions.
The solutions of the scattering and radiation potentials for region I are expressed as
where the superscript (e) emphasizes that the solution is valid in the exterior region. The eigenfunctions Rn(kpr) and Zp(kpz) are well known and their definitions are

Here, Hn denotes the Hankel function of the first kind while Kn is the modified Bessel function of the second kind. The parameter kp (p = 1, 2, 3, …) is the pure imaginary root of the dispersion equation ν = k tanh(kh). Because of the symmetry of the circle shape, the incident wave angle might be set to zero (β = 0) without losing generality.
In the interior region, the diffraction potential may be written in the form
where the eigenfunction of the z variable is defined as

It is easy to verify that the above eigenfunctions satisfy the governing equation, the linearized free-surface condition, the impermeable sea bottom condition and the continuity of the normal velocity at the porous sheet. Inserting the eigenfunction into the remaining Darcy-type boundary condition yields a transcendental equation for the parameter κq given by

This equation works like a ‘dispersion relation’ for the eigenvalue κq in the interior region. It should be noted that the solutions of this algebraic equation are no longer real numbers or pure imaginary numbers as in conventional cases such as in the exterior region. They are generally complex numbers. A detailed discussion on the deduction of the eigenfunctions for the interior region has been given by Yu and Chwang.10

When the radiation potentials due to the forced oscillation or the vibration of the net are considered, there exists a normal velocity nj (j = H or mn) in the boundary condition (see equations (7) and (8)). Therefore, a particular solution ψj is needed to account for this normal velocity. The radiation potentials in the interior region then take the forms
The particular solution for the forced heaving oscillation can be easily obtained by inspection. It takes different constants in the upper part and lower part of the region respectively, i.e.

To determine the particular solution ψmn, it is noticed that the natural modal function Wmn itself satisfies a two-dimensional Helmholtz equation (see equation (10)). Therefore, only an appropriate eigenfunction of the z variable is required. Consequently, the particular solution can be expressed in the form
The boundary value problem governing the function f¯(β¯mnz) is derived by separation of variables. It is stated as

This problem is similar to that satisfied by the eigenfunction f(κqz) used in the general solution given by Yu and Chwang.10 Unlike the complex eigenvalue κq, the parameter β¯mn is a real number and is predetermined from the boundary condition of a freely vibrating circular membrane. The solution of equation (28) can be expressed as
where the denominator Δmn takes a form similar to the left-hand side of equation (23), just replacing κ by βmn, and is given by
Its value will never be zero since it is impossible for a real number to be a solution of equation (23), as mentioned earlier.
In equations (21), (24) and (25), the superscript (i) is added to indicate that the expression is valid in the interior region.

The unknown coefficients A and B appearing in the expansion of potentials can be determined by matching these two solutions at the common surface r = a by means of the continuity of the potential and its normal derivative as follows

The expressions for the potentials are inserted into the above matching conditions and the orthogonal properties of the eigenfunctions are applied. A set of linear algebraic equations is obtained. As the solutions of the linear equations, the coefficients A and B are thus determined and the velocity potentials are solved. The tedious procedure will be omitted here to save space.

sec.title: Hybrid method
sec.p: To solve the boundary value problem given in the second section for an arbitrarily shaped net sheet, a hybrid method is adopted in the present work. The fluid domain is divided into two regions by a virtual circular cylinder SR with a radius R extending from the water surface to the sea bottom. The outer region, i.e. r > R, is denoted as region I, where the potential is expressed by the series expansion of eigenfunctions. In the inner region, Green’s theorem is applied and the potential is expressed by an integral over the boundary surfaces. In the present work, the body is a thin sheet without thickness. To avoid singularity, the inner region is further divided into two parts. The column beneath the net is called region III. For example, in the case of a rectangular net, this is the cuboid within the ranges –a < x < a, –b < y < b and –h < z < –d. For a circular net, region III is the cylinder under the net, within the ranges r < a and –h < z < –d. The remaining inner region is named region II. The common surface between region II and III is denoted as SV (see Figure 1(b)).
In the outer region, i.e. region I, the potentials are expanded into series of eigenfunctions such as

where the eigenfunctions Rn(kpr) and Zp(kpz) have the same definition as in equation (20). The superscript (I) of the potential indicates the region of its validation and this convention is applied throughout this section. The unknown coefficients A and B are determined simultaneously when solving the integral equation in the inner region.

On the other hand, Green’s theorem is applied to the inner region, i.e. to region II and region III respectively. The velocity potential at a field point P in the region can be expressed by an integral over the boundary surface surrounding the region, which is given by
where Q indicates the source point. The constant CP denotes the solid angle at point P. It can be readily evaluated by setting φ = 1 in the above integral, giving
The Rankine source and its mirror image of the sea bottom are adopted as the Green’s function in the present work, which can be written as
where

The boundary surface of region II consists of the inner part of the free surface SF, the surface SB of the sea bottom, the upper face of the net surface S0 and the common surfaces with regions I and III, i.e. SR and SV respectively. On the other hand, the boundary surface of region III is made up of the lower surface of the net S0, the common surface SV and the surface SB of the sea bottom.
When the field point P is located at the boundary, equation (33) becomes a set of integral equations for the unknown value of the potential on the boundary, which can be written as follows.
For region II
For region III

In driving the above integral equations, corresponding boundary conditions have been applied over different parts of the boundary surface. On the surface SB of the sea bottom the integral vanishes owing to the boundary condition (equation (6)) and the symmetry of the Green’s function with reference to SB. Based on the continuity of the potential and its normal derivative, the expression for the eigenfunction expansion defined in region I, i.e. equation (32), may be inserted into the integrand with r = R over the common surface SR. On the free surface, the normal derivative of the potential is replaced by νφ according to the linear free-surface condition (equation (5)). On the common surface SV, the continuous conditions are applied once again and it is noticed that the normal vector over this surface is in the opposite directions when viewed from region II and region III respectively. Therefore, on the common surface Sin, it may be assumed that
On the net surface, the porous condition of equation (7) is applied with the understanding that nS=−∂ϕI/∂ϕI∂∂n .
The integral equations (35) and (36) are discretized with quadratic boundary elements and then solved numerically.

sec.title: Motion equation and hydrodynamicforces
sec.p: The net sheet is deformed under the effect of hydrodynamic forces. The deflection of the net is governed by the forced vibration equation of membrane13 as given below

The right-hand side, i.e. Δp(x), represents the difference of the hydrodynamic pressures on the two sides of the membrane. Substituting the expansion for ζ(x, t) given in equation (1), the motion equation can be rewritten as
Then, both sides of equation (39) are multiplied by a mode function Wpq(x) and integrated over the net surface S0. The results can be expressed in the form
The coefficient Mpqmn, as an element of the mass matrix, is defined by the integral
where

Because of the orthogonal properties of mode functions, the mass matrix is diagonal, as shown above. The coefficient Cpqmn is the element of the stiffness matrix caused by the tension distributed over the membrane, which is also diagonal as expressed by
The generalized radiation potential φmn makes a contribution to the hydrodynamic coefficients, i.e. added mass and damping, which can be calculated by the integral

In the motion equation (40), a superscript (D, H) is added to the exciting forces of mode pq (the right-hand side of the equation) and the modal amplitude of the deformation to indicate whether the force (and consequently the deflection) is caused by the incoming waves (the diffraction potential) or the forced heaving oscillation (the radiation potential). These exciting forces are calculated from the integral of the corresponding potential in the following forms
Solving the final form of the motion equation (40), the modal amplitude ζmn is determined.

On the other hand, without the elastic effect of the net deformation, the wave exciting force, added mass and damping of the heaving motion can be evaluated by regarding the net as rigid. These conventional hydrodynamic forces are calculated from the following integrals: the integral for the wave exciting force of heave given by
and the integral for the added mass and damping given by

In order to make a comparison with the experimental data, it is necessary to calculate the total vertical forces acting on the circumference of the net. It is the total tension, projected on to the vertical direction, along the perimeter C0 of net sheet as shown in the following line integral
where t denotes the anticlockwise unit vector along the girth while k is the vertical unit vector. Based on the assumption of small deformation, the unit normal vector n may be approximated as

where ∇2 denotes the two-dimensional gradient operator in the horizontal plane. Once the modal amplitudes are solved from the motion equation, the force acting on the circumference may be calculated as
The superscript (D, H) has the same meaning as mentioned before.

sec.title: Experimental arrangement
sec.p: To validate the theory and calculation, model tests are carried out in the Ocean Engineering Basin of the Institute of Industrial Science, The University of Tokyo. The basin measured 50 m long by 10 m wide with a depth of 5 m. Two kinds of test are performed for each model in the present work. The first one is the diffraction test, i.e. the model is fixed in a train of regular waves. The second one is forced heaving oscillation in still water. In both of the tests, the hydrodynamic forces and the deformation of the net are measured.

sec.title: Net models
sec.p: The net models used in the experiments are all square shaped with dimensions of 0.3 m × 0.3 m. The nets are made of textile cord, the diameter of which is equal to 0.003 m. The model nets are knitted with three different twine spacings. The intervals between the twines are set to 0.01 m, 0.015 m and 0.02 m corresponding to the opening ratios (the ratio of the empty space to the total area of the net) τ = 0.53, 0.64 and 0.74 respectively. The pre-tension is required to be equally distributed over the net. A special knitting device is designed and constructed. The device can maintain a uniform tension on each side of net when being knitted. For each net with different spacings, two values of pre-tension, i.e. T = 10 N/m and T = 50 N/m, are applied respectively. Therefore, six net models are tested in the present experiment. The nets are all installed on a rigid metal frame. To reduce the effect of the frame on the measured forces, a frame without net is pretested. The value measured from the empty frame is subtracted from the values measured in the net tests.

sec.title: Experimental devices and parameters
sec.p: The net models are horizontally fixed to a forced oscillation device via a load cell that measures the forces acting on the models. To measure the displacement of the net deformation, two video cameras are installed beneath the model. The deformation of the net is videoed during the tests. The recorded graphical image is analysed with an image analysis software system to obtain digital data on the displacement. The layout of the experimental arrangement is shown in Figure 2. The net models are submerged at a depth equal to 0.12 m.

In the diffraction tests, the forced oscillation device is fixed and regular waves are generated at different wave periods and amplitudes. The wave period varies within the range from 0.5 s to 1.8 s, and the wave amplitude is determined by setting the wave slope to 0.03, 0.05 or 0.09. In the forced heaving tests, the net models are driven to heave by the oscillation device. The frequency and amplitude of heave motions are the same as those used in the diffraction tests.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: All the measured data such as the forces, waves and heaving motions are treated by means of Fourier analysis. From the forces measured in the diffraction tests the wave exciting force acting on the net is obtained. In the forced heaving tests, the force amplitude FH is divided by the acceleration of the forced oscillation and separated into the real part and the imaginary part to obtain the added mass and damping coefficient respectively, i.e.
where M represents the total mass driven into heaving oscillation beneath the load cell.

As mentioned earlier, the deformations of nets recorded by two video cameras are all graphic images. The images should be transformed to digital data before the Fourier analysis. This is performed by the special software named DIPP-Motion Pro, which has been developed by DITECT Corp. The displacement of any specified point on the net can be detected from its video image by means of the software. Then, the obtained digital data can be treated with Fourier analysis in the same way as the other quantities.

To make a comparison with the calculated results, it is required to extract the modal amplitudes from the measured displacement of the net. For this purpose, several points (xk, yk) (k = 1, 2, … K) evenly distributed on the net are specified. After treatment by the software DIPP-Motion Pro and the Fourier analysis, the complex amplitude ζ~(xk,yk) of the displacement can be obtained for each selected point. According to the discussion given in the third section, this amplitude of displacement may be expanded into a series of natural modes such as

Here ζ~mn is the modal amplitude to be extracted. If the number of the specified points is equal to the total number of modal amplitudes to be obtained, i.e. K = MN, equation (51) becomes a linear algebra equation system and the unknown modal amplitudes are determined by its solutions. To improve the accuracy, more points than the total number of required modes are chosen. The linear system becomes over-determined but the unknown modal amplitudes can be solved by means of the least-squares method.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: To compare the calculated results with the experiment data, the porous-effect parameter σ used in the porous boundary condition (7) at the net should be related to the opening ratio τ adopted in the experimental arrangement. This is expressed by an empirical formula based on the equivalent linearization of the Forchheimer equation14 and given by
where ε = Ak0 is the wave slope, with A and k0 representing the incident wave amplitude and wave number respectively. A detailed discussion has been given in previous work.15
In the figures presented in this section, the experimental results are illustrated with symbols while the calculated results are plotted in curves.

sec.title: Hydrodynamic forces
sec.p: The hydrodynamic forces acting on the net are discussed in this section. The results are plotted against the non-dimensional wave number ak0 in Figures 3 to 6.

caption.p: Wave exciting forces acting on rigid nets with the same area, calculated by the hybrid method (open circles) and the method of eigenfunction expansion (solid curve).

Wave exciting forces acting on square nets with different opening ratios τ = 0.53, 0.64 and 0.74 and pre-tensions T = 10 N/m and 50 N/m, with a side length of the nets equal to 0.3 m and with the wave slopes (a) ε = 0.03, (b) ε = 0.05 and (c) ε = 0.09. The experimental measurements are designated by various symbols while the calculated results are represented by curves.

Measured and calculated added masses of square nets with different opening ratios τ = 0.53, 0.64 and 0.74 and pre-tensions T = 10 N/m and 50 N/m, with a side length of the nets equal to 0.3 m and with the wave slopes (a) ε = 0.03, (b) ε = 0.05 and (c) ε = 0.09. The experimental measurements are designated by various symbols while the calculated results are represented by curves.

Measured and calculated damping of square nets with different opening ratios τ = 0.53, 0.64 and 0.74 and pre-tensions T = 10 N/m and 50 N/m, with a side length of the nets equal to 0.3 m and with the wave slopes (a) ε = 0.03, (b) ε = 0.05 and (c) ε = 0.09. The experimental measurements are designated by various symbols while the calculated results are represented by curves.

sec.p: First, the calculated result of the hybrid method is compared with that of the eigenfunction expansion method. A square-shaped net sheet and a circular net sheet with the same area and porosity are chosen as an example. The problem for the square-shaped net is solved by the hybrid method while the eigenfunction expansion method is applied to the circular net. The wave exciting forces acting on the rigid nets are presented in Figure 3. It can be observed that these two results are in good agreement within the numerical accuracy.

Wave exciting forces measured from diffraction tests with various wave slopes are illustrated in Figure 4 together with the calculated results. The exciting force is acting on the elastic nets and its value is normalized by ρgAa2 with ρ designating the water density. As shown in the figures, a smaller wave exciting force acts on the net with a larger opening rate τ. Generally, the pre-tension of the nets does not play an important role in the magnitude of the wave exciting forces. Compared with the experimental measurement, the calculated results are underestimated for the wave exciting forces especially in the range of large wave numbers.

As the results of forced heaving tests, the hydrodynamic coefficients, i.e. the added mass coefficients A33 and the damping coefficients B33 of elastic nets, are plotted in Figure 5 and Figure 6 respectively together with the calculated results. The added mass is non-dimensionalized by ρa3, while the damping is normalized by ρωa3.

According to the observations in Figures 5 and 6, similar to the exciting forces, the added mass coefficients A33 and the damping coefficients B33 are not significantly affected by the pre-tension. Their values decrease as the porosity of the net increases.

The measured data on B33 generally agree with calculated results but a discrepancy between the experimental and calculated results can be seen in the figures of the added mass coefficients A33, especially for larger values of ak0. This may be caused by an inappropriate type of porous-effect parameter σ, which is a real number in the present work. In other studies, such as the work of Isaacson et al.,16 a complex number is employed for the parameter σ. The imaginary part of σ takes account of the inertial effect, which leads to a phase difference between the fluid velocity and the hydrodynamic pressure. Another reason for the discrepancy might be the non-linearity of the flow, which includes the non-linear interaction between the net deformation and the ambient flow. The pressure drop through the net could be modelled as a quadratic function of a characteristic cross-flow velocity, for example, as used in the work of Molin and co-workers.17,18

sec.title: Deformation of net
sec.p: As a demonstration, the deformation of a net with an opening ratio of 0.62 is presented along three lines, i.e. x = 0, x = 0.2a and x = 0.4a, in Figure 7. The pre-tension is equal to 50 N/m. The net is forced into heaving oscillation at a frequency ωa/g=1.265, equivalent to ka0 = 1.6. The illustration is within half the period Tp of the oscillation with a time step of Tp/12. It can be seen that the measured shape shown in Figure 7(a) agrees with the calculated shape given in Figure 7(b) but the calculated magnitude is smaller than the measured value.

caption.p: (a1)–(a6) Experimental measurements and (b1)–(b6) calculated results of the instantaneous deformation of a square net within half a period along lines (i.e. x = 0 (solid curves), x = 0.2a (broken curves) and x = 0.4a (dot-dashed curves)) with a time step of Tp/12, where the net is forced into heaving oscillation at a frequency ωa/g=1.265 (with an opening ratio τ = 0.62 and a pre-tension T = 50 N/m): (a1) t = 0; (a2) t = Tp/6; (a3) t = 2Tp/6; (b1) t = 0; (b2) t = Tp/12; (b3) t = 2Tp/12; (a4) t = 3Tp/12; (a5) t = 4Tp/12; (a6) t = 5Tp/12; (b4) t = 3Tp/12; (b5) t = 4Tp/12; (b6) t = 5Tp/12.

sec.p: To examine this in detail, the modal amplitudes of mode m = n = 1 and m = 3, n = 1, are plotted in Figure 8 and Figure 9 respectively for the case of a forced heaving oscillation. Although the calculated results become close to the measured data at lower ak0, the discrepancy in the other range is obvious, especially for a large heaving amplitude. One of the reasons that causes the disagreement is the difficulty in measuring and analysing the net displacement. The position of the two video cameras should be adjusted to obtain a broader viewing angle facing the net, which may improve the video image of the normal displacement.

caption.p: Modal amplitude ζ11 in the representation (equation (1)) of deformation for square nets under forced heaving oscillation at a frequency ωa/g=1.265, with different opening ratios τ = 0.53, 0.64 and 0.74 and pre-tensions T = 10 N/m and 50 N/nm and with the wave slopes (a) ε = 0.03 and (b) ε = 0.05. The experimental measurements are designated by various symbols while the calculated results are represented by curves.

Modal amplitude ζ31 in the representation (equation (1)) of deformation for square nets under forced heaving oscillation at a frequency ωa/g=1.265, with different opening ratios τ = 0.53, 0.64 and 0.74 and pre-tensions T = 10 N/m and 50 N/m and with the wave slopes (a) ε = 0.03 and (b) ε = 0.05. The experimental measurements are designated by various symbols while the calculated results are represented by curves.

sec.p: More sampling points might be needed to improve the accuracy of the image analysis.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: As a first step to investigate the hydrodynamic behaviour of a sea cage, the problem of a single elastic net sheet fixed in waves or forced into heaving oscillation is studied in the present work. The problem is formulated within the scope of the linear hydroelastic theory. The net is regarded as a porous membrane. The boundary value problem is solved by means of the eigenfunction expansion for a circular net or by the hybrid method for an arbitrary shape. A series of experiments with various porosities, pre-tensions, periods, etc., is carried out to measure the forces and deformation of the net. As the result of the comparison between the calculated values and the measured data, the predicted damping agrees with the experimental measurement. However, the other hydrodynamic forces, such as the added mass and the wave exciting force, and the deformation of the net are underestimated by the calculation. To improve the calculation, a more sophisticated boundary condition at the net should be considered in future work, which will take the inertial and non-linear effects into account properly. The experimental arrangement should be adjusted and the procedure of image analysis should be improved to increase the accuracy of the experimental data.
